xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: Manuscript received March 25, 2010; revised August 19, 2010 and November 17, 2010; accepted December 12, 2010. Date of publication January 24, 2011; date of current version July 20, 2011. This work was supported in part by the Ryerson University Postdoctoral Fellowship Program, in part by the Ontario Early Researcher Award Program, and in part by the Canada Research Chair Program. The work of Z.-G. Hou was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 60 775 043. This paper was recommended by Associate Editor W. J. Wang.

organization.$: Key Laboratory of Complex Systems and Intelligence Science

head.citation-title: Finite-time attitude tracking control for spacecraft using terminal sliding mode and chebyshev neural network
head.abstracts: A finite-time attitude tracking control scheme is proposed for spacecraft using terminal sliding mode and Chebyshev neural network (NN) (CNN). The four-parameter representations (quaternion) are used to describe the spacecraft attitude for global representation without singularities. The attitude state (i.e., attitude and velocity) error dynamics is transformed to a double integrator dynamics with a constraint on the spacecraft attitude. With consideration of this constraint, a novel terminal sliding manifold is proposed for the spacecraft. In order to guarantee that the output of the NN used in the controller is bounded by the corresponding bound of the approximated unknown function, a switch function is applied to generate a switching between the adaptive NN control and the robust controller. Meanwhile, a CNN, whose basis functions are implemented using only desired signals, is introduced to approximate the desired nonlinear function and bounded external disturbances online, and the robust term based on the hyperbolic tangent function is applied to counteract NN approximation errors in the adaptive neural control scheme. Most importantly, the finite-time stability in both the reaching phase and the sliding phase can be guaranteed by a Lyapunov-based approach. Finally, numerical simulations on the attitude tracking control of spacecraft in the presence of an unknown mass moment of inertia matrix, bounded external disturbances, and control input constraints are presented to demonstrate the performance of the proposed controller. Â© 2011 IEEE.
